Overview
[Cookbook: How to build a IPDR Exporter]

Here is a list of the steps needed to integrate the IPDR exporter into a network element, for exporting data. This assumes a straightforward implementation on a Unix-like operating system (e.g., Linux, VxWorks, QNX, etc.), done by a single experienced engineer.

The largest amount of time is given to testing. This can often be combined with other testing of the network element. The second largest amount of time is for design issues. The actual implementation can be done quite quickly.

Define what data will be generated and how the data will be used Data is useless if it doesn't fulfill some need or if it is difficult to use. Multiple uses for the data should be considered (e.g., for both accounting and for QoS monitoring). See also Cookbook: Determine downstream processing needs.
Read the overview documentation The minimum for this is the Cookbook: How to build a IPDR Exporter, the sample code, and the overview of the protocol in IPDR/SP 2.1 Specifications Document.
Define the data Create the C/C++ structures for the data and write the IPDR templates for accessing it. See Cookbook: Define templates.
Define which features of the API will be used This step includes determining the sizing parameters (see Cookbook: Sizing), estimating performance issues, and how the IPDR exporter will be integrated into the platform.
Write the configuration callback Typically, this is a lookup into a table of key/value pairs. We assume that the network element already provides a function for reading in the values. See Cookbook: Integrating configuration.
Define the monitoring, event and error handling See Cookbook: Error and event handling and Cookbook: Integrating IPDR monitoring.
Add the IPDR start, stop, and "send" calls to the code The start and stop code must be added at an appropriate point in the network element's start-up and shut-down code. The "send" calls may simply be added to the code when some accounting even occurs; or they may require a separate thread which outputs data at specified intervals.
Integrate the IPDR MIB See Cookbook: Integrating the IPDR MIB
Test functionality Configure the collector and examining the output to ensure it is what is expected (this may require writing simple scripts).
Stress test and failure test Extended tests at maximum data rates and with maximum number of transmitters (clients). Failure tests can be labor-intensive because of the need to physically plug cables in and out, turn power on and off, etc.

If porting of the platform is needed (see Cookbook: Implementing the platform-dependent layer (porting)), the following additional knowledge is needed:

  • The platform's operating system (threads, synchronization, non-blocking socket I/O, signal handling, time and date handling);
  • POSIX functions for threads, synchronization, non-blocking socket I/O, signal handling, time and date handling;
  • Low-level debugging on the platform;
